notes: Host-controlled. Breakout rooms decide verbally, host locks choice.
Every scenario must read like: 'hereâ€™s the mess â†’ here are your constraints â†’ what do you do?'
Outcomes are deterministic and short; scenarios carry most of the context.

wheelSlices.description: Quotes, spreads, slippage, and the eternal question: 'is this a product or a math paper?'

scenarios.title: RFQ vs CLOB Cage Match
scenarios.subtitle: Liquidity is ready. Philosophy is not.
body: It is dangerously close to launch. Growth wants 'tight spreads.' Finance wants 'understandable revenue.' Risk wants 'predictability.'
Engineering says: 'We can ship RFQ now.' The alternative (CLOB) is... a diagram, three meetings, and a dream.
You also have a new constraint: leadership wants a clean story for why pricing is 'fair' without triggering a 45-minute debate about microstructure.
scenarios.question: What do you do?

outcome.headline: Reality achieved.
outcome.narrative: You ship. Spreads are a little mysterious, but the product exists in the physical universe. Someone still asks 'when CLOB?' within 4 minutes.

outcome.headline: Purity acquired. Launch not included.
outcome.narrative: You achieve the cleanest architecture in a PowerPoint deck. The launch date becomes 'a vibe' and morale becomes 'a concept.'

outcome.headline: Everyone hears what they want.
outcome.narrative: You ship RFQ and promise CLOB. The roadmap now includes: CLOB, and 17 follow-ups to define what CLOB means.

outcome.headline: You invented a third option: chaos.
outcome.narrative: You try to blend RFQ and CLOB. Engineering ships something that works, but only under a full moon and a Jira ritual.

scenarios.title: Slippage Data Summoning Ritual
scenarios.subtitle: Finance needs a number. Talos has 'feelings'.
body: Finance asks the simplest question that has ever destroyed a roadmap: 'How much slippage should we expect?'
Talos can provide historical slippage data, but it's in a place described only as: 'a portal'.
You need an answer for launch readiness, but you also need to not commit to a number you'll regret on a slide.
scenarios.question: What do you do?

outcome.headline: Spreadsheet emotions unlocked.
outcome.narrative: You ship. Finance builds a model from vibes. The model becomes a living being and asks for PTO.

outcome.headline: Data obtained. Momentum sacrificed.
outcome.narrative: You wait for clean data. It arrives. So does a calendar invite titled 'Slippage Governance Working Group'.

outcome.headline: Adult compromise detected.
outcome.narrative: You pick safe assumptions and clearly disclose. Everyone is mildly unhappy, which means it worked.

outcome.headline: You built a knob. The knob will be used.
outcome.narrative: You introduce a range. Stakeholders immediately choose the most optimistic end and tattoo it onto a deck.

wheelSlices.description: The product wants to move money. Risk wants to move slowly.

scenarios.title: Instant Funding: The Forbidden Fruit
scenarios.subtitle: Growth wants fireworks. Risk wants a seatbelt factory.
body: Growth: 'If funding isn't instant, people bounce.' Risk: 'If funding is instant, fraud arrives early and brings friends.'
Engineering can support instant fundingâ€”but only if limits + step-up rules are crisp and consistent across surfaces.
You must decide what launches now vs what becomes 'phase two' (a.k.a. the shadow realm).
scenarios.question: What do you do?

outcome.headline: Signups spike. So does chaos.
outcome.narrative: You open the gates. The funnel looks amazing. Fraud also discovers electricity and starts speedrunning your controls.

outcome.headline: Safe, coherent, slightly sleepy.
outcome.narrative: The product is safe. The funnel is... contemplative. Someone asks if we're 'anti-growth on purpose.'

choices.label: Instant funding with tight limits + step-up

outcome.headline: You ship, but the flow gains two new religions.
outcome.narrative: You land a balanced policy. The experience now includes step-up logic that feels like a moral exam.

outcome.headline: Internal beta becomes a demolition derby.
outcome.narrative: You validate quickly with a smaller blast radius. Employees immediately find the weirdest edge cases on earth.

scenarios.title: Rounding Strategy Wars
scenarios.subtitle: Decimals are where trust goes to die.
body: You need minimums and rounding rules for trading that don't feel like a magic trick.
If you round too aggressively, users feel cheated. If you show full precision, the UX looks like a spaceship console.
Support is already drafting macros for 'where did my cents go?'
scenarios.question: What do you do?

outcome.headline: Simple UX. Complex feelings.
outcome.narrative: The UI is clean. Support tickets are not. Every ticket includes the phrase: 'it's not about the money, it's about the principle.'

outcome.headline: Accuracy achieved. Readability lost.
outcome.narrative: You are technically correct (the best kind). Users now need a calculator to feel joy.

outcome.headline: Two doors. Everyone stops yelling.
outcome.narrative: Default is simple, advanced is precise. Both camps feel respected and move on to their next argument.

outcome.headline: Congrats, you invented dust.
outcome.narrative: You ship without clarity. Microscopic leftovers accumulate until someone has $0.04 in five places and rage awakens.

wheelSlices.description: Whatâ€™s in MVP? Whatâ€™s on the roadmap? Whatâ€™s in the void?

scenarios.title: USDC-Only MVP
scenarios.subtitle: The calmest product youâ€™ll ever ship. The loudest questions youâ€™ll ever get.
body: To reduce complexity, the launch plan is: member launch supports USDC as the stablecoin anchor.
This makes policies, limits, and flows much simplerâ€”especially while buy/sell/hold stabilizes.
But marketing wants to say 'crypto platform' without everyone replying: 'soâ€¦ one coin?'
scenarios.question: What do you do?

outcome.headline: Coherent product. Mild internet disappointment.
outcome.narrative: You ship something stable and safe. Twitter asks if the other coins are 'in beta spiritually.'

outcome.headline: More coins, more meetings.
outcome.narrative: You expand scope. The backlog becomes sentient. It requests a manager.

outcome.headline: Ship reality, sell vision.
outcome.narrative: You frame USDC as the foundation. Stakeholders accept it because the narrative is crisp and oddly soothing.

choices.label: Employee launch with more assets first

outcome.headline: Employees become the canary mine.
outcome.narrative: You test asset sprawl internally. You learn a lot. Mostly about how creative employees are with money movement.

scenarios.title: Trending Coins: The Illusion of Taste
scenarios.subtitle: The backend isn't ready, but the homepage wants confidence.
body: Your L1 wants a 'Trending' section because empty space looks like fear.
Backend isn't done. The honest option is 'no trending yet.' The shady option is 'hardcode a list and pray.'
Design asks: 'Can we at least make it look intentional?'
scenarios.question: What do you do?

outcome.headline: Curated. Incorrect. Confident.
outcome.narrative: You ship a list. The list trends toward being wrong. Someone asks why the product is 'shilling.'

outcome.headline: Minimal UI, maximal honesty.
outcome.narrative: You ship without trending. The product looks clean. Marketing quietly starts a doc titled 'Discovery Gap.'

outcome.headline: Vendor-powered confidence.
outcome.narrative: You integrate a feed. It works great until the feed hiccups during a demo and everyone learns humility.

outcome.headline: You died on the hill of 'Popular.'
outcome.narrative: You delay to ship trending. The feature is nice. The calendar is furious.

wheelSlices.description: Without search, everything is just vibes and scrolling.

scenarios.title: Search Is Late, But Vibes Are Early
scenarios.subtitle: Discovery is hard when users canâ€™t find anything.
body: Search is slipping on mobile and web. Without it, the crypto catalog feels like a warehouse with the lights off.
You can launch with curated lists and navigation hacks, but it's not the same as real discovery.
Stakeholders are split: 'Ship!' vs 'If users can't find coins, what's the point?'
scenarios.question: What do you do?

outcome.headline: You shipped. Users wandered.
outcome.narrative: The product launches. People scroll. A lot. Session time goes up for all the wrong reasons.

outcome.headline: Discovery saved. Momentum wounded.
outcome.narrative: You delay and ship real search. The product is stronger. The launch story now includes a sentence that begins: 'Due to...'

outcome.headline: Boutique crypto shop era.
outcome.narrative: You ship curated discovery. It feels intentional. You quietly become a product editor for one sprint.

outcome.headline: Mobile users notice. Loudly.
outcome.narrative: Web looks great. Mobile feels like a different product. Someone says 'parity' three times and the room chills.

scenarios.title: Tearsheet Beautiful, History Missing
scenarios.subtitle: Gorgeous charts. Fewer receipts.
body: Tearsheets are ready and they look incredible. Transaction history / activity is behind because of prioritization and complexity.
Without history, some users will ask: 'Did my trade happen, or did I hallucinate it?'
You need to pick what the MVP feels like: a polished showroom, or a transparent ledger.
scenarios.question: What do you do?

outcome.headline: Showroom unlocked.
outcome.narrative: It looks premium. Users love the visuals. Support starts hearing: 'Where do I see what I did?'

outcome.headline: Trust won. Time lost.
outcome.narrative: You delay and ship transparency. It's the right call. Everyone quietly mourns the original timeline.

outcome.headline: Just enough receipts to survive.
outcome.narrative: You ship a small activity view. It prevents chaos. Everyone agrees never to speak of the missing features again (for now).

outcome.headline: The banner becomes the product.
outcome.narrative: You ship with disclaimers. Users read them as: 'not finished.' Stakeholders read them as: 'not a problem.'

wheelSlices.description: Legal clarity vs user friction: pick your poison.

scenarios.title: The Agree Button of Destiny
scenarios.subtitle: Do you ship trust, or ship paperwork?
body: You need crypto document generation + signing. A full DocuSign-like flow adds weeks and feels like closing on a house.
Legal is open to an 'Agree' button, but only if the copy is precise and auditability is solid.
The product must be compliant, but also not an obstacle course that makes users quit out of spite.
scenarios.question: What do you do?

outcome.headline: Compliance squintsâ€¦ and nods.
outcome.narrative: You ship the Agree flow. Audit trail is clean. Someone says 'we'll harden it later' and everyone pretends that's real.

outcome.headline: Legally immaculate. UX spiritually harmed.
outcome.narrative: You ship a fortress. Users feel like theyâ€™re adopting a dragon. Drop-off improves your risk metrics accidentally.

outcome.headline: The adult compromise returns.
outcome.narrative: You ship with lightweight consent and a strong record. Everyone is mildly satisfied, which is how you know it's correct.

outcome.headline: You invented a regulatory horror story.
outcome.narrative: You ship without proper consent. Legal appears like a wizard and turns your roadmap into a cautionary tale.

scenarios.title: Copy Approval Gauntlet
scenarios.subtitle: The word 'guarantee' just got banned mid-sentence.
body: UX copy is in review. Compliance wants precision. Marketing wants excitement. Product wants it to be understandable by humans.
You have 48 hours. Stakeholders keep suggesting micro-edits that add 3 new legal implications each.
The only constant is: someone will find one more word they hate.
scenarios.question: What do you do?

outcome.headline: Words locked. Feelings unlocked.
outcome.narrative: You freeze copy and move on. It's safe. Half the room is annoyed, which means you avoided 37 more edits.

outcome.headline: Perfection achieved. Time disappeared.
outcome.narrative: Copy becomes beautiful. Launch becomes theoretical. Everyone gains a new respect for words and a new hatred for time.

outcome.headline: Bland. Safe. Efficient.
outcome.narrative: You use standard language. It's not exciting, but it's bulletproof. Users are slightly bored; regulators are delighted.

outcome.headline: Hero moment. Minor typo. Eternal shame.
outcome.narrative: You ship copy. It passes review. Later someone notices a comma that changes the meaning of life.

wheelSlices.description: You want alpha access. Security wants a time machine and a checklist.

scenarios.title: Expose Gateway on extWeb
scenarios.subtitle: To test externally, you must summon Security.
body: You need alpha testers to access the crypto product on external web surfaces.
Security review is required. The review queue is real. The deadline is also real. These realities are in conflict.
Engineering can do a tight allowlist and minimal exposure, but only if everyone agrees 'temporary' doesn't mean 'forever.'
scenarios.question: What do you do?

outcome.headline: Slow. Safe. Weirdly satisfying.
outcome.narrative: You do it properly. It takes time. You sleep better. The timeline sends you passive-aggressive DMs.

outcome.headline: You ship alpha with guardrails.
outcome.narrative: You keep the blast radius small and learn fast. Security is not thrilled, but they respect the boundaries.

outcome.headline: Temporary becomes a lifestyle.
outcome.narrative: You bypass the process. It works. Then you spend the next month paying 'temporary debt' with 'temporary tears.'

outcome.headline: Internal testing intensifies.
outcome.narrative: You test internally and avoid exposure risk. Employees become expert testers and occasional chaos agents.

scenarios.title: Pen Test Findsâ€¦ Something
scenarios.subtitle: Medium severity issue, unclear exploitability.
body: A pen test reveals a medium severity issue. The report says: 'unclear exploitability.' Which is consultant for: 'good luck sleeping.'
Engineering can fix it with a clean patch, but it risks destabilizing other parts of the launch build.
Leadership asks: 'Are we safe?' Security asks: 'Define safe.'
scenarios.question: What do you do?

outcome.headline: You chose correctness over speed.
outcome.narrative: You fix it now. Launch slows. Your future self sends a thank-you note via time travel.

outcome.headline: A grown-up compromise (again).
outcome.narrative: You mitigate the risk and document clearly. Everyone is slightly uneasy, which is the correct amount of uneasy.

outcome.headline: Speedrun mode activated.
outcome.narrative: You accept risk and hit the date. The launch deck looks great. Security develops a new eye twitch.

outcome.headline: The feature livesâ€¦ quietly.
outcome.narrative: You gate the risky surface behind a flag. You ship the core. The flag becomes your emotional support blanket.

wheelSlices.description: Universal pain. Maximum relatability. Minimal dignity.

scenarios.title: The Drive-By Stakeholder
scenarios.subtitle: They were quiet for 8 weeks. Now they have thoughts.
body: A senior stakeholder appears 36 hours before launch. They start with: 'Quick question.' This is never quick.
They request a 'small' change that is actually three product decisions and a new integration.
You have one goal: protect launch without starting a political war.
scenarios.question: What do you do?

outcome.headline: You added it. You also added consequences.
outcome.narrative: You accept the change. The build survives. The team does not. A new meeting series is born.

outcome.headline: Scope defended. Politics awakened.
outcome.narrative: You protect launch. The stakeholder respects you publicly and plots privately. Classic.

outcome.headline: Token deployed like a tranquilizer dart.
outcome.narrative: You promise it later. The stakeholder feels heard. Future-you feels haunted.

outcome.headline: Cardboard-feature shipped.
outcome.narrative: You ship a thin version. It technically exists. It also technically disappoints everyone equally.

scenarios.title: Prod Incident During Employee Beta
scenarios.subtitle: The dashboard is red. The calendar is also red.
body: During employee beta, alerts fire. Something is wrong. The only thing you know for sure is: it picked the worst possible time.
Half the room says rollback. Half says hotfix. One person says 'letâ€™s just monitor it' and everyone stares.
You need to choose a path that keeps the launch moving without creating a future crime scene.
scenarios.question: What do you do?

outcome.headline: Correct, boring, heroic.
outcome.narrative: You rollback. Things stabilize. The team exhales. Someone says 'we should have done this sooner' and is correct.

outcome.headline: Hero mode, high variance.
outcome.narrative: You hotfix. It works. Everyone feels powerful and slightly terrified of themselves.

outcome.headline: The flag saves you.
outcome.narrative: You gate the problematic path. The day is saved by a boolean. The boolean becomes sacred.

outcome.headline: You chose vibes. Vibes chose violence.
outcome.narrative: You monitor. The incident escalates. The postmortem begins writing itself in the background of everyone's mind.

catastrophes.title: Catastrophe: Emergency All-Hands
catastrophes.description: An emergency all-hands appears on everyoneâ€™s calendarâ€¦ for right now.

effect.ruleText: Next round timer is reduced to 45 seconds.

catastrophes.title: Catastrophe: Red Flag Flood
catastrophes.description: Compliance enters the chat. They brought 14 follow-up questions and a spreadsheet.

effect.ruleText: Next round must be from 'Security Review Boss Level' or 'Consent & Signing Shenanigans' slices.

catastrophes.title: Catastrophe: Team Sanity Meltdown
catastrophes.description: The team has achieved a new state of being: 'operationally present, spiritually absent.'

effect.ruleText: Fast Follow tokens are disabled for the remainder of the game.
